rows.name: help_text
rows.value:
Given two numbers, Which one is more? Switch between that question and the nearly identical problem, Which one is less?

For example: Which is more, 4/8 or 3/8? Similarly this could be: Which is less, 4/8 or 3/8?

rows.name: topics_text
rows.value: The goal is to develop number sense for fractions. Which characteristics of the numerator and denominator make a fraction larger or smaller in value? Which techniques can a student develop that help them easily see which fraction is smaller or larger?

rows.name: advice_text
rows.value:
These routines develop various strategies for understanding the values of fractions and comparing them. Students can always fall back on converting the two fractions to have a common denominator and then compare that way. However, that approach gives up opportunities for deeper understandings of fractions, and it is not nearly as playful or interesting.

Possible strategies include:
* Use the same denominator and see how the numerators compare. If you have 4/8 and 3/8, why make it harder than it needs to be?
* If two fractions have the same denominator, the one with the smaller numerator will be smaller.
* If two fractions have the same numerator, the one with the larger denominator will be smaller.
* Use a benchmark number to simplify the comparison. To stay with the 4/8 and 3/8 example, 4/8 is 1/2. 3 is less than half of 8, so 3/8 is less than 1/2. Whole numbers and very simple fractions like halves and thirds can make good benchmarks.
* Sometimes look at the distance from a benchmark number. For example, 9/10 is 1 - 1/10 and 7/8 is 1 - 1/8. The larger the number you subtract from the same number, the smaller the number becomes.
* Treat one of the fractions as division. If you want to compare 1/2 and 2/3, your student can say that 2 is more than half of 3, so 2/3 must be bigger.

rows.name: intro_2_text
rows.value: Each task has two numbers. The students should decide which one is the biggest and which is the smallest.
